Hi @iler, no that is not necessary I think. I've merged your change into the trunk and pushed it to the Apache Software Foundation repositories. The way it works is that we don't merge directly on github but instead merge the commits to trunk, sign the commits, and then once we push it the asfgit bot will come by to sync the repo back to github and close the pull request. Your change is now [in the current trunk](https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/dd6aaba856d5f3ed6e8a05c4f92465a968af450d) and the change has been documented [here in the CHANGES file](https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/080b343e0983f2a22f7647b4fd8cebb3339adbe2). @micafer I spotted one more bug, when you raise `OpenStackException` you only pass in the value but it also requires a http_code as argument.     

See `class ProviderError(LibcloudError):`
```
def __init__(self, value, http_code, driver=None):
```


```
                raise OpenStackException("Security group direction incorrect "
                                         "value: ingress or egress.")
```

This would cause:
```
In [4]: from libcloud.common.openstack import OpenStackException

In [5]: raise OpenStackException("Security group direction incorrect value: ingress or egress.")
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-7f11a6689d5c> in <module>()
----> 1 raise OpenStackException("Security group direction incorrect value: ingress or egress.")

TypeError: __init__() takes at least 3 arguments (2 given)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OpenStackException                        Traceback (most recent call last)

Hi @ktdreyer, this is great. 

I noticed on the [project about page](http://libcloud.apache.org/about.html) that it mentions:

```
Supported Python Versions
Libcloud supports the following Python version:

Python 2.5,
Python 2.6,
Python 2.7,
PyPy,
Python 3 (since 0.7.1)
Support for Python 2.4 has been dropped in Libcloud 0.4.0.
```

I did some digging and found that [in this PR](https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1150) support for [anything under 2.7 was dropped](https://github.com/pquentin/libcloud/commit/6cf1a800c8f88429df705165c380b23439886420) so I think this PR should be fine. Python 2.5 and 2.6 which don't have the assertIsNone aren't tested in the [travis file anymore anyway](https://github.com/apache/libcloud/commit/25c4d99b50017e4fd233ad03fa56d337e99ef451). I don't know where the source code for http://libcloud.apache.org is managed but that about page should probably be updated.

```

In [4]: myvolume = _

In [5]: myvolume.extra
Out[5]:
{'attachments': [{u'device': u'/dev/vdb',
   u'id': u'abc09342-d8e1-49af-8df0-613dafaee6a9',
   u'serverId': u'abc945f9-01ce-4eb7-ac10-92798c677abc',
   u'volumeId': u'abc09342-d8e1-49af-8df0-613dafaee6a9'}],
 'created_at': u'2018-12-04T14:21:45.000000',
 'description': u'testvol',
 'location': u'nova',
 'metadata': {u'attached_mode': u'rw',
  u'contents': u'testvol',
  u'readonly': u'False'},
 'snapshot_id': None,
 'state': u'in-use',
 'volume_type': None}
```

after:
```
In [7]: conn.ex_get_volume('abc09342-d8e1-49af-8df0-613dafaee6a9')

{'attachments': [{u'attached_at': u'2018-12-04T14:22:25.000000',

   u'device': u'/dev/vdb',
   u'host_name': None,
   u'id': u'abc09342-d8e1-49af-8df0-613dafaee6a9',
   u'server_id': u'abc945f9-01ce-4eb7-ac10-92798c677abc',

I'm not sure what the policy is in regards to breaking changes in libcloud but I personally would prefer if we keep it as easy as possible to stay up to date with the library.

Hi @cheald, could you add a simple unit test to https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/da9ae84e7c20d8921f573a880732da7b44f28fa6/test/compute/test_vcloud.py#L84? Perhaps just calling _get_auth_headers and checking if `version=5.5` is in the Accept key of the dict would be sufficient. Unit tests both serve to document behavior and prevent stuff from accidentally being changed later on, so even though that would be a pretty trivial test I think it would still hold value.

Also I have a question here as I am not that familiar with the vcloud APIs. Would this break anything for not 'Newer VCD installs' or would that also keep working as intended?

the pyopenssl dependency, is that specific to this driver?

I assume the RSA private keys in this pull request are test data :-)

@tonybaloney Yes, it is specific to the nttcis loadbalancer driver.  Those keys and crts are test data and self signed.  Is there any requirements or restrictions on importing python modules, whether built-in or third party installed?  I have another branch using python-dateutil.  Thanks!

Sure, I'll see about wiring that up. I didn't include one mostly out of ignorance of where/what to test. :)

I've only started looking into using libcloud with our new hosting provider - they provide a vCloud Director install with the version 30.0 API. I'm still quite new to the whole vCloud ecosystem, but logically, I don't believe this should break anything for "not newer installs" - this is the 5_5_Connection subclass, which only applies when the requested version is 5.5. Earlier versions use the 1_5_Connection.

Unless there's a reason that benefits multiple drivers, we really try to avoid adding extra dependencies to this project.

Another alternative is to make it option, like the vsphere/pysphere package https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/vsphere.py#L28-L39
@tonybaloney  Pyopenssl has been made optional, but has been placed in tox.ini similar to pyvsphere.
